webTitle: The Adam Smith Institute's long shot on economic forecasting

fields.bodyText: If you want to know the likely outcome of the next general election or the Eurovision song contest, consult a bookmaker. Bookies' odds have a long and honourable record of being ahead of the game, for good reason: they reflect the opinions of specialists and insiders who are prepared to back their views with hard cash. Could the principle work for economic forecasting? The Adam Smith Institute, in mischievous mode, has encouraged Paddy Power to open betting markets covering the rate of UK inflation and the rate of unemployment on 1 June 2015. It's 9-4 that CPI inflation will be 3.01%-4% and 5-2 that unemployment will still be in the 7%-8% range. "The Bank of England's economic forecasts have been wrong again and again," says the thinktank. It wonders if the fabled "wisdom of crowds" can do better. It's an eye-catching idea that relies on a crowd actually turning up to bet. In the case of the inflation rate, serious punters (or at least those in the City) may think there are already plenty of places to express a view, such as the futures market in interest rates. A market for betting on the unemployment rate is more novel – and timely, given the Bank's new forward guidance regime. The Adam Smith Institute is dreaming if it thinks the government would ever get rid of its experts and outsource its forecasts to "prediction markets". But the spice of competition is no bad thing. And, with the Bank's less than glorious recent record in forecasting, mischief-making should be welcomed.

webTitle: Nationwide was always likely to prefer softly-softly approach to lending

fields.standfirst: If the government wanted to kickstart SME lending market, it should have taken responsibility for creating more competition
fields.body:
So, Nationwide is not about to storm into the market for lending to small and medium-sized businesses (SMEs). It's a case of 2014, probably; and, even then, slowly. We can only speculate whether the argy-bargy with the Bank of England's Prudential Regulation Authority over leverage ratios influenced the building society's thinking on timing. What is clear, though, is that the government had high hopes that Nationwide, and indeed the Co-op Bank, would provide stiffer competition to the big banks in business lending. But ministers were being too naive. They had overlooked Co-op Bank's fundamental weaknesses, now horribly revealed. And Nationwide, albeit a much stronger institution, was always likely to prefer a softly-softly approach.

If the government wanted to breathe more life into the SME lending market, it should have taken responsibility itself for creating more competition.

webTitle: Kentz's latest figures will fail to dispel takeover talk

fields.standfirst: The Irish energy contractor's interim numbers look unlikely to help it put up stout defence against Amec advances
fields.body:
Kentz, the Irish contractor to the oil, gas and mining industries, started on the back foot when Amec, a practised acquisition machine, came knocking last week.

The problem was simple: the Malaysian investors who had successfully rescued Kentz in the 1990s had sold half their 26% stake a year ago, at 430p a share. Since one of the investors is also Kentz's chairman, there was a credibility issue in resisting Amec's indicative offer at 565p-580p, or about £700m.

A lot can happen in a year to change a company's value, of course. But if Kentz is serious about putting up a stout defence, it may have to produce stronger stuff than was contained in yesterday's interim numbers. Revenues were up 2%, to $775m, and reported pre-tax profits were 3% higher, at $52.7m. That was all in line with analysts' forecasts but was still lacking a certain transformational quality.

True, the backlog of orders – up 12%, to $2.8bn – looks solid enough. Kentz is also chatting about a busy period for bidding for new work, and expressed its confidence by pushing the half-year dividend up 20%. All the same, there were few specific gems to encourage long-standing shareholders to stay loyal.

They may reflect that if the bid buzz evaporates Kentz may once again be viewed as a well-run but ultimately lower-margin contractor whose shares traditionally trade at a discount to larger, engineering-focused rivals.

We shall see. Amec clearly hasn't offered its best shot yet, and it would have to go well above 600p to persuade Kentz to open its books, especially if the German M+W Group is still sniffing. But the share price, steady at 565p, is saying Kentz has not killed the takeover talk yet.

webTitle: Private health firms attacked over charity tax relief

fields.standfirst: Grimsey Review claims charitable status of Nuffield Health allows it to avoid paying £8m in business rates
fields.body:
Private healthcare groups registered as charities are facing criticism over the avoidance of almost £9m in business rates. The news comes as the Competition Commission is set to deliver its review of the UK's £5bn private medical industry on Wednesday morning.

The watchdog is expected to impose restrictions on hospitals' ties to consultants who choose where to send patients and publish clearer information about their performance. The investigation follows complaints by a new operator, Circle Healthcare, about barriers it had faced in entering the market. Another main area of concern is competition within London, where private hospital provision is dominated by HCA, a US company.

The review is not expected to question the charitable status of private healthcare firms such as Nuffield Health. But the UK's second largest charity faces a new attack from retailers. Campaigners are pushing for changes to business rates they say are punishing small independent retailers.

The Grimsey Review, an independent report into high streets led by former retail boss Bill Grimsey, will claim that Nuffield Health, which runs hospitals, medical centres and gyms, avoided an estimated £8m in business rates last year. Other private groups including King Edward VII's Hospital, the London Clinic and the Hospital of St John & St Elizabeth are thought to have avoided a total of £1m in business rates.

Paul Turner-Mitchell, a Rochdale shopkeeper who is a member of the Grimsey Review team, said: "There needs to be a debate on who gets charitable rate relief because we can't afford to keep squeezing the high street to death. Most people will be scratching their heads and wondering why lucrative private healthcare companies are getting tax breaks. They are not hard-pressed charities they are commercially focused organisations."

Nuffield Health, which last year achieved a 12% rise in turnover to almost £645m, is a not-for-profit organisation which does not have shareholders or pay dividends, but it does have 47 members of staff earning more than £100,000 a year with the highest paid on more than £840,000, according to its 2012 accounts. The company made a £22.5m "operating surplus" last year on top of £21m the year before.

Nuffield said in a statement: "Our charitable purpose is to work towards the advancement of health. Everything we do is dedicated to this and every pound that we earn is invested back into providing high quality hospitals and modern health and wellness facilities."

The company said it offered around 25% of its services at a maximum of £1 a day or £360 a year and also provided services to over 100,000 NHS patients a year.

fields.standfirst: Estate agent firm reveals expansion plans over next five years after confirming future flotation on the London Stock Exchange
fields.body:
Foxtons, the famously aggressive estate agents, has said it expects to open 50 new branches across London over the next five years, having identified at least 60 new local markets.

As the agency confirmed its plans to float on the London Stock Exchange, when it expects to raise £55m and free the company of debt for the first time in several years, it also said it saw potential to expand into the south-east of England "in the longer term".

Foxtons has 40 offices in London and two in Surrey.

Bosses at the agents, known for its branded fleet of Mini Coopers and brightly-coloured offices, are expected to make around £100m from the float which is likely to value the business at up to £500m when it lists next month.

The current owners, private equity group BC Partners, will sell some of its shares along with the directors, in a listing that marks the end of an impressive turnaround of fortunes for its investment.

BC Partners bought Foxtons from founder Jon Hunt at the height of the property boom in 2007. It paid £360m in a highly leveraged deal, but in the property market collapse the company found itself unable to make its debt repayments.

This led to the Bank of America and Mizuho taking control of the business until BC Partners invested a further £50m and last year bought back the business from the banks.

Hunt subsequently used the cash from the sale to build a property empire which has left him worth an estimated £925m, according to the Sunday Times Rich List.

Around 50% of the issued share capital in Foxtons will be available at the flotation and a dividend of between 35% to 40% of profits after tax has been suggested, with the possibility of special dividends.

The current management team will remain in place, with Michael Brown as chief executive and Gerard Nieslony chief financial officer.

BC Partners will also have a non-executive director from the company on the board. The chairman will be serial boardroom member Garry Watts, who is chairman of Spire Healthcare and deputy chairman of Stagecoach Group.

Foxtons issued a note of caution ahead of the float, warning: "The directors believe that residential property sales transaction volumes in London may recover, although the extent and the timing of any recovery is uncertain."

But housebuilders and estate agents have been broadly optimistic, especially in London, after the introduction of government schemes to boost the housing market, Funding for Lending and Help to Buy.

In March the UK's biggest estate agent, Countrywide, launched a successful flotation and upmarket housebuilder Crest Nicholson also returned to the stock market. Countrywide shares jumped 12.5% on their first day of trading.

Foxtons has performed strongly this year, reporting underlying profits up 14.3% to £19.4m in the first six months of the year on revenues of £62.6m.

The average Foxtons property sale price was £476,000 in 2012 and it sells properties in the £200,000 to £1.4m sales brackets, charging an average commission of 2.5%.

One in three houses sold in the City, one in four flats in Ladbroke Grove and one in five flats in Chelsea was sold through Foxtons last year, according to the company.

webTitle: Bank of England denies its rules forced Nationwide into business lending delay

fields.standfirst: Threadneedle Street rebuts suggestion that Nationwide's decision was due to capital strength demands
fields.body:
The Bank of England has denied that its insistence on Nationwide holding a bigger capital cushion had forced the UK's largest building society to slow its launch of small business lending.

Nationwide admitted plans to expand lending to small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are unlikely to take effect until 2014 at the earliest.

It said plans to begin lending to smaller firms were still under development but "moving slowly"; , it denied a report that it had shelved a planned launch date for later this year.

A spokesman for Nationwide said: "We are building our expertise in this area and hiring people experienced in working with SMEs. These things are happening, albeit they are moving slowly."

The Bank of England rejected any suggestion that Nationwide's decision to hold off from a launch into the SME sector was due to its demands on capital strength.

A spokesman added: "The plan agreed with Nationwide to meet the 3% leverage ratio in 2015 will not result in them restricting lending to the real economy. Therefore it is wrong to blame their SME decision on the regulator."

The lender's slowness to offer loans to SMEs will disappoint ministers concerned that small firms continue to be starved of credit.

Nationwide's entry into the market has been seen by business secretary Vince Cable as a way to increase competition and break the dominance of Lloyds and Royal Bank of Scotland.

However, regulators warned the lender had rapidly expanded its mortgage business while still wrestling with an overhang of bad commercial property loans.

It was rebuked in July by the regulator, the Prudential Regulatory Authority (PRA), for running an aggressive lending policy without adequate reserves to insure against a possible collapse.

Analysts at credit ratings firm Standard & Poor's followed with a warning that a doubling in the losses on commercial property loans to £450m weakened the lender's financial position.

S&P downgraded Nationwide's credit rating this month and signalled that further downgrades could follow without a rapid improvement.

"These impairment charges have hindered Nationwide's internal capital generation. As a result, we have revised down our assessment of its risk position to 'adequate' from 'strong'," it said.

The lender revealed plans to enter the SME loans market last year, where lending has shrunk as banks retreat and demand wanes.

At the time boss Graham Beale described it as a "natural extension of what we can do".

A Nationwide spokesman said: "We have previously said that it is our strategic intention to enter the SME banking market and that we will do this at the right time for the society and our members. That remains our intention."

He said the lender was unable to give an official launch date.

"We have never talked about it being this year, just sometime in the future. We have never committed to a date."

The spokesman was reacting to a report in the Financial Times that a planned launch later for this year had been scrapped.

The newspaper said it understood that a service offering loans to SMEs was unlikely to be ready before 2016.

webTitle: Global markets hit by political tensions over Syria - as it happened

fields.standfirst:
• European stocks fall as Syria crisis escalates - closing prices
• French jobless hits record high
• Brent crude oil hits six-month high
• How Syria is spooking markets
• In Italy, Berlusconi problem threatens stability
fields.body:
5.49pm BST

Closing post

And that's a good moment to stop for the day. My colleagues will be tracking the Syria situation in our Middle East blog:

Syria crisis: live updates.

I'll be back tomorrow, when Bank of England governor Mark Carney's will give his maiden speech in Nottingham. Until then, goodnight and thanks for the comments. GW.

5.48pm BST

5.46pm BST

French unemployment hits another high

Some late news from France -- the number of people out of work hit a new record high in July.

The total registered as out of work increased by 6,300 to 3,285,700 people - a 0.2% rise on June's figure. This means the French jobless total has increased for the last 27 months.

As Reuters points out, president Francois Hollande promised to get unemployment falling by the end of 2013. Time is running out...

Updated at 5.47pm BST

5.42pm BST

Oil price climbs higher

While European stock markets ended the day down, the oil price continues to climb this evening. Brent crude is now up $3.50 per barrel, or over 3%, at $114.29, while New York crude is up a similar amount to $108.98.

As Shires of England pointed out in the comments section below, this could be bad news for the eurozone's recovery:

CMC's Michael Hewson makes the same point:

If prices are sustained at these levels we could well see some form of demand destruction which could derail some of the recent recovery in Europe’s economies.

Updated at 5.42pm BST

5.26pm BST

It wasn't a great day for Turkey, where the lira weakened to a new record low against the US dollar and the stock market tumbled by around 4.7.

This followed a less-than-inspiring performance by its central bank governor, who urged investors to 'believe in me and win', before revealing he would soon be off on a short holiday.

Business Insider has the details.

5.05pm BST

Syria, Fed fears and eurozone all blamed

Brenda Kelly, senior market strategist at IG, says today's stock market selloff was due to three factors - increased tensions with Syria, continued uncertainty regarding US Federal Reserve tapering and trouble in the eurozone.

She writes

Jitters in equity markets were felt from the open, as the likelihood of a US-led military response to the tensions in Syria heightened.

The resulting lack of clarity and ongoing uncertainty with respect to Fed tapering has prompted investor profit-taking with the banks, with resource stocks bearing much of the brunt. On the flipside, the precious metals market is firmly in the black, with Fresnillo adding 7.97% on sturdier gold and silver prices. Randgold Resources was also in favour, adding 5.61%.

Political uncertainty in Italy is adding to trouble in the eurozone; the mere notion that financial reforms will not go ahead has negatively impacted Italian prices and weighed on the Italian bourse. Elsewhere, the German IFO business climate index beat expectations, rising to 107.5 from last month’s 106.2, but the data did little to pacify investor caution. The prospect of yet another bailout for Greece was an additional fly in the ointment, and Greek finance minister Yannis Stournaras has stated that an additional smaller amount may be required in 2014.

5.02pm BST

Here's the biggest risers and fallers on the FTSE 100 today:

Updated at 5.06pm BST

4.52pm BST

European markets close in the red

Europe's stock markets have posted their biggest fall in two months, after a day of nervous trading dominated by the prospect of military action against Syria.

Trading just finished for the day, with heavy losses on some indices. That knocked 1.5% off the FTSEurofirst 300 – made up of shares from across Europe – which is its biggest daily drop since June 24 (according to Reuters data).

Volatility in the markets also jumped by the most since February.

Rikin Thakrar, senior dealer at Spreadco, commented:

The markets are jittery as Russia and Iran issued strong warnings against any Western military action. The trouble in Syria, along with U.S. debt ceiling worries and tapering talk, have put stock markets firmly on the back foot.

Here's the closing prices:

• FTSE 100: down 51 points at 6440, - 0.8%

• German DAX: down 192 points at 8242, -2.28%

• French CAC: down 98 points at 3968, -2.4%

• Spanish IBEX: down 255 points at 8394, -3%

• Italian FTSE MIB: down 397 points at 16579, -2.3%

Updated at 5.03pm BST

4.21pm BST

And still the oil price keeps climbing, with both Brent Crude and NYMEX light crude (the two benchmarks) now up by over $3 per barrel today.

4.18pm BST

Over in Greece, a business group has warned that tens of thousands more small firms will collapse by the end of this year. That's despite a bank recapitalisation programme that was meant to shore up its economy.

Associated Press has the details:

A survey is warning that some 40,000 small businesses in Greece are likely to close in the second half of 2013 at a cost of up to 90,000 jobs despite a major bank rescue program implemented before the summer.

However, the small business survey conducted by the Hellenic Confederation of Professionals, Craftsmen and Merchants (GSEVEE) between July 10 and 16 and published Tuesday found that the 50 billion euro ($66.7 billion) bank recapitalization was likely to result in a modest decline in the rate of closures, from an estimated 55,000 in the first half of the year.

3.29pm BST

US consumer confidence rises

In an encouraging sign for the US economy, American consumer confidence has risen this month - with people feeling more confident about their employment and earning prospects.

That's according to the latest figures from the Conference Board. Its monthly measure of consumer outlook (full details here) spiked to 81.5 points, much healthier than July's reading of 80.3 and beating expectations of a fall to 79.0.

The 'future expectations' section of the report shows a significant rise, while the 'current conditions' measure declined a little.

Lynn Franco, Director of Economic Indicators, explained:

Consumers were moderately more upbeat about business, job and earning prospects. In fact, income expectations, which had declined sharply earlier this year with the payroll tax hike, have rebounded to their highest level in two and a half years.

Consumers’ assessment of current business and labor market conditions, on the other hand, was somewhat less favorable than last month.

No impact on the stock market, though, with the Dow now down 111 points.

2.42pm BST

Wall Street opens

As predicted, shares dropped once Wall Street opened as US traders react to the latest developments over Syria.

webTitle: Tiffany's sales growth powered by China

fields.standfirst: Jewellery chain's global sales were a mixed picture, with Japanese numbers falling and a flat US performance
fields.body:
Tiffany, the New York-based jeweller, said its second-quarter profits were up 16% to $106m (£68.3m) driven by strong sales in China.

The company, which sponsored Baz Luhrmann's The Great Gatsby, said revenue from stores open at least a year were up 5%. Total sales for the quarter were $956m.

Defying the continued fallout from the eurozone crisis, sales in mainland Europe and the UK were up 11%. Sales in the Americas were 2% higher overall and, in Japan, they fell 14%, dragged down by a weaker yen.

But Asia-Pacific sales climbed 20%, led by strong results in China, which is considered a bellwether for the luxury market.

The results came as figures showed Americans' confidence in the economy inched closer to its highest point in five-and-a-half years on growing optimism that hiring and wages could pick up in coming months.

The Conference Board said today that its consumer confidence index rose to 81.5 in August, up from 81 in July and just below June's 82.1 reading, which was the highest since January 2008.

Consumers' income expectations, which fell this year after a January tax increase, rebounded to the highest level in two-and-a-half years, said Lynn Franco, director of the Conference Board's economic indicators.

Although consumers were more confident about the future, their assessment of the economy dipped slightly in August.

Consumers' confidence in the economy is watched closely because their spending accounts for about 70% of US economic activity.

After hitting bottom at 25.3 in February 2009, the index has bounced back, but it has yet to attain a reading of 90, which signals a healthy economy.

webTitle: FTSE falters on Syria concerns while RBS hit by new calls to split bank

fields.standfirst: Equity markets unsettled by growing political tensions while oil and gold both move higher
fields.body:
With markets under pressure on concerns about military action in Syria, not to mention continuing concerns about central banks ending their support programmes, Royal Bank of Scotland was among the leading fallers.

Away from the macro issues, RBS was hit by new calls by an influential group of MPs to split it into a good and bad bank, amid speculation Treasury officials could be cooling on the idea. Its shares fell 14.2p to 330.1p as analysts said this reminder of the political interference surrounding the bank made it unattractive to investors.

Meanwhile Standard Chartered slipped 55p to 1437.5p after instability in its key Asian markets thanks to the Syrian situation.

Overall the FTSE 100 finished 51.13 points lower at 6440.97 despite a better than expected German confidence survey which showed business optimism at its best levels for sixteen months. Michael Hewson, senior market analyst at CMC Markets, said:

The uncertainty being created by the potential for some form of military action in Syria, political uncertainty in Italy and the timing of a Fed tapering program appears to have convinced a lot of people that the risks of getting involved in these markets somewhat outweighs any potential rewards, hence today's sharp falls.

International Airlines Group led the FTSE 100 lower after a broker downgrade and concerns about rising fuel prices.

The owner of British Airways and Iberia fell 15.3p to 300.5p, with Investec moving from buy to hold, albeit with a 320p price target. Analyst James Hollins said:

The IAG first half performance was way ahead of expectations and we have accordingly adjusted our 2013 forecasts (earnings per share up 30%) to reflect the strength of the first half trading and margin, as well as including Vueling following completion of the acquisition.
Our longer-dated forecasts also increase, albeit our relatively cautious view on premium traffic yields and ongoing difficulties at Iberia (the initial cost-out initiatives have been exceptionally positive, although the next steps may be incrementally less effective) result in a relatively more muted earnings enhancement. While we remain huge fans of the Willie Walsh Iberia/Vueling strategy, we now see limited upside to our new... price target of 320p [given pressure on both premium and short-haul yields.]

With Syrian tensions helping to lift the Brent crude oil price by nearly 3% to $114 a barrel, Investec said:

While jet fuel pricing has stabilised somewhat after a seemingly unstoppable rise between 2009 and 2011, the recent rise in jet fuel prices and continued oil pricing at more than $100 a barrel are still cause for concern and a severe headwind to airlines' profitability.

Among the miners, Antofagasta fell 30.5p to 884.5p after first half earnings declined by 31.2%, hit by lower copper prices. Eurasian Natural Resources Corporation lost 8.6p to 215p and Rio Tinto dropped 76.5p to 2992.5p.

But with gold seeing its haven status rekindled by the geopolitical tensions, precious metal specialists were on the rise. Mexican miner Fresnillo jumped 87p to £13.10 while Randgold Resources rose 210p to £53.35.

Petrofac put on 108p to £13.73 after the oil services group - whose shares have been heavily shorted on concerns about its move into a challenging offshore market - said it expected a stronger second half performance. First half revenues dropped 12.5% but this was in line with City expectations. Analyst Andrew Whittock at Liberum Capital said:

The shares have been weak this year following [an] earlier downgrade of expectations, fewer new contract awards than hoped, concerns over fixed price contacting and doubts over the investment in a high-spec installation vessel. We do not share the market's concerns. We retain our 1550p price target and believe Petrofac is good value with potentially significant growth to be delivered from new Integrated Energy Services and Engineering & Construction businesses.

Elsewhere Marks & Spencer climbed 7.5p to 479.1p in the wake of an upgrade from Citigroup, which moved from neutral to buy with a target price lifted from 470p to 535p. Citi said:

The combination of recent, material upgrades to UK economic growth forecasts, and M&S management initiatives have markedly improved the credibility of double-digit 2015 and 2016 M&S earnings per share growth forecasts. We argue that this should underpin the group's current undemanding valuation metrics.
Primarily as a consequence of significant IT, logistics and supply chain investment programmes over the last 3-4 years, M&S general merchandise should begin to see both revenue and gross margin improvements from 2014.

AstraZeneca slipped 1.5p to £32.45 after the pharmaceuticals group announced the acquisition of US cancer specialist Amplimmune for up to $500m. Societe Generale issued a sell note, saying:

In our view, the Amplimmune acquisition is an expensive way to acquire an unencumbered pre-clinical asset. To justify a $500m price tag, [pipeline drug] AMP-110 would need to generate $6bn in peak sales (with a launch in 2018) at a 70% plus peak operating margin.
We have previously argued that AstraZeneca will have to acquire aggressively if it is to get revenues and earnings anywhere near close to growth again over the next five to six years and that acquiring growth would likely be expensive. In the last 18 months, Astra acquired six companies (including a 50% stake in Amylin) for up to $7.3bn. We expect that as the combination of these six acquisitions, together with Astra's in-house R&D pipeline, will still not be sufficient to return revenues or earnings to a growth trajectory before 2019, investors should expect more M&A deals from Astra and likely more expensive deals at that.

Finally Motive Television saw its shares more than double, prompting the software group to announce it was not aware of any reason for the rise. Pointing to bulletin board speculation, it said it had not entered into a contract with Google Chromecast and was not in talks about such a contract. But it was in discussions with a number of companies about various possible deals. The comments took some of the shine off the shares, which closed 52% higher at 0.019p.

webTitle: Former JP Morgan banker arrested in Spain over 'London Whale' charges

fields.standfirst: Javier Martin-Artajo is accused of trying to cover up Bruno Iksil's spiralling multibillion pound losses
fields.body:
A former JP Morgan banker has been arrested in Spain 10 days after US authorities filed charges against him over the "London Whale" affair that cost the bank $6bn (£3.9bn).

Javier Martin-Artajo, who was the direct supervisor of Bruno Iksil, the trader dubbed the "London Whale", handed himself in on Tuesday in Madrid following a conversation with the specialist fugitive unit of the Spanish police.

Martin-Artajo, a 49-year-old Spanish national, is wanted by US authorities on four charges of conspiracy, keeping false books and records, wire fraud, and making false filings to the Securities and Exchange Commission watchdog.

His passport has been confiscated pending extradition proceedings, a spokeswoman for the Spanish national court said. He faces up to 20 years in prison if convicted of the most serious charges, although extraditions from Spain to the US are rare.

He is accused of trying to inflate the value of trading positions held on JP Morgan's books. The mismarking allegedly took place as the traders tried to hide mounting losses in an illiquid derivatives market, where they had made outsized bets.

Martin-Artajo, who was paid $11m a year for his work as head of Europe for JP Morgan's chief investment office (CIO), was charged by the New York attorney general, Preet Bharara, earlier this month. Bharara alleges that as the London losses mounted Martin-Artajo and former junior JP Morgan trader Julien Grout began to "creatively cook the books".

Iksil, who avoided criminal charges by agreeing to help prosecutors build a case against his former colleagues, is said to have warned Martin-Artajo in an email that the size of his trading positions had become "scary".

"I don't know where he [Martin-Artajo] wants to stop, but it's idiotic," Iksil, who was paid $6.8m in 2011, told colleagues as the losses spiralled.

FBI assistant director George Venizelos said it was a story of a "group of traders who got in over their heads, and to get out, doubled down on a series of risky positions". He added: "In the first quarter of 2012 boom turned to bust, as the defendants, concerned about losing control to other traders at the bank, fudged the numbers on their daily book, and in some cases completely made them up. It brought a whole new meaning to cooking the books."

Prosecutors allege JP Morgan issued its results for the quarter to 31 March 2012 on the basis of false and fraudulent information about the value of complex credit derivatives conducted by the bank's CIO. Those results were later restated by $660m as a result of misvalued trading positions, the prosecution alleges.

Martin-Artajo was head of credit and equity trading of the CIO, working out of London but visiting New York. Iksil worked for him, as did Grout. The prosecutors said JP Morgan later discovered that 107 of 132 trading positions were marked in the books at more favourable prices than they should have been.

Martin-Artajo's lawyer, who was not available for comment on Tuesday, has previously said he "is confident that when a complete and fair reconstruction of these complex events is completed, he will be cleared of any wrongdoing".

A lawyer representing Grout, a French national, told Reuters his client had not committed any wrongdoing. He has not yet been arrested and is believed to be in France. "No, they have not arrested Julien, nor would they because France does not extradite their own citizens," Grout's US lawyer, Edward Little, told Reuters. "We are in discussions with US prosecutors about how we will proceed, but no decision has been made yet."

JP Morgan declined to comment on the arrest.

webTitle: Billabong profits wiped out as labels lose favour

fields.standfirst: Australian surf clothing company in negotiations with private equity groups as brand is deemed worthless
fields.body:
Billabong has fallen to an A$860m (£498m) loss after the value of its surfwear and fashion brands crumbled in two years from A$614m to A$90m.

The Australian company reported that global sales for the year fell 13% to A$1.34bn, reflecting store closures, weak European economies and the fading allure of its brands. The Billabong label is now deemed worthless, according to the company's accounts. The company has staggered through shake-ups and failed buyout offers. It said it was in the final stages of debt-refinancing negotiations that would allow the business to be rebuilt.

"2013 has clearly been a tumultuous year with all that has gone on," Peter Myers, the acting chief executive, told investors.

The chairman, Ian Pollard, said Billabong wanted to secure a deal to reduce its A$320m debt and fund restructuring.

"Since 1973, Billabong has faced some tough times and has come through them stronger and will do so again on this occasion," he said.

The company has reached a US$470m (£300m) deal with the US-based Altamont Capital Partners, but the Billabong board is also considering a rival offer from the US hedge funds Oaktree and Centerbridge Partners.

Billabong's 2012-13 loss included a A$604m writedown in goodwill and the value of its brands, plus a A$129m write-off from the sale of Nixon, its US watch brand. Revenue fell by 12.6%, with the effect of currency movements excluded, to $A1.35bn.

Billabong said it was making progress on the sale of West 49, its Canadian retail chain, and had closed 158 underperforming stores. Billabong shares dropped three cents or 5.3%, to 53.5¢. The company's market value is A$271m, down from A$907m less than two years ago.

webTitle: Local produce v convenience food: Share your stories

fields.standfirst: What was in the last meal you ate? A mixture of food sourced from the local market alongside supermarket shortcuts? Pure fresh produce or a ready meal? We want to see what's in your shopping basket and how you're making your money stretch for meals in the UK. Share your story with us here

webTitle: British Airways owner IAG falls on downgrade and fuel price concerns

fields.standfirst: Airline group's rating cut by Investec while Syrian tensions lift oil price by 1.5%
fields.body:
International Airlines Group is leading the FTSE 100 lower after a broker downgrade and concerns about rising fuel prices.

The owner of British Airways and Iberia is down 12.5p at 303.3p, with Investec moving from buy to hold, albeit with a 320p price target. Analyst James Hollins said:

The IAG first half performance was way ahead of expectations and we have accordingly adjusted our 2013 forecasts (earnings per share up 30%) to reflect the strength of the first half trading and margin, as well as including Vueling following completion of the acquisition.
Our longer-dated forecasts also increase, albeit our relatively cautious view on premium traffic yields and ongoing difficulties at Iberia (the initial cost-out initiatives have been exceptionally positive, although the next steps may be incrementally less effective) result in a relatively more muted earnings enhancement. While we remain huge fans of the Willie Walsh Iberia/Vueling strategy, we now see limited upside to our new... price target of 320p [given pressure on both premium and short-haul yields.]

With Syrian tensions helping to lift the Brent crude oil price by nearly 1.5% to $112 a barrel, Investec said:

While jet fuel pricing has stabilised somewhat after a seemingly unstoppable rise between 2009 and 2011, the recent rise in jet fuel prices and continued oil pricing at more than $100 a barrel are still cause for concern and a severe headwind to airlines' profitability.

webTitle: Renold plans to shut Manchester chain plant

fields.standfirst: Engineering group identifies overcapacity and will consult with employees over proposed closure
fields.body:
Renold, a maker of industrial chains and power transmission equipment, plans to close its plant at Bredbury in Manchester, putting 230 jobs at risk.

The company, which has issued a number of profit warnings in recent months, has conducted a strategic review under a new management team, and as part of this it has concluded the Bredbury chain plant is not economically viable.

It will begin a consultation period with its employees which it hopes to conclude by the end of October. Chief executive Robert Purcell said:

We know this will be a period of uncertainty for our staff at Bredbury and we are committed to consulting fully with our employees and their representatives. We do however have a pressing need to reduce our cost base if the group is to realise its future potential.

Renold's shares are currently more than 4% lower 28p.

webTitle: Miners drop as markets fall on Syria fears, but Petrofac gains on outlook hopes

fields.standfirst: Antofagasta hit by copper price declines, as investors face political concerns and Fed tapering fears
fields.body:
Miners are leading the way lower as the market reacts badly to the prospect of US military intervention in Syria.

Investors are taking profits after a two day rally at the end of last week, pushing the FTSE 100 56.62 points lower to 6435.48. Continuing uncertainty over when the US Federal Reserve will begin easing its asset buying programme, one of the key supports for the market, is adding to the downbeat mood. Ishaq Siddiqi, market strategist at ETX Capital, said:

Jittery stock markets this Tuesday on the prospects of US military intervention in Syria affecting risk-sentiment. Even a stronger than expected German IFO survey [consistent with the progress in all German economic indicators] has failed to put a smile on the markets' face.
Oil prices have crept up on geopolitical tensions in the Middle East, while safe haven bonds in Europe – UK gilts and German bunds – are in favour on the risk-averse tone seen in the market this morning. We also have to remember now that with a relatively respectable US and European earnings season now wrapping up, investors are likely to spend most of the session deciphering economic data out of the US.

Among the miners, Antofagasta has fallen 23p to 892p after first half earnings declined by 31.2%, hit by lower copper prices.

Eurasian Natural Resources Corporation is down 7.1p at 216.5p and Rio Tinto has dropped 66.5p to 3002.5p.

But Petrofac has put on 44p to £13.09p after the oil services group - whose shares have been heavily shorted on concerns about its move into a challenging offshore market - said it expected a stronger second half performance. First half revenues dropped 12.5% but this was in line with City expectations. Analyst Andrew Whittock at Liberum Capital said:

The shares have been weak this year following [an] earlier downgrade of expectations, fewer new contract awards than hoped, concerns over fixed price contacting and doubts over the investment in a high-spec installation vessel. We do not share the market's concerns. We retain our 1550p price target and believe Petrofac is good value with potentially significant growth to be delivered from new Integrated Energy Services and Engineering & Construction businesses.

Elsewhere Marks & Spencer has climbed 11.9p to 483.5p in the wake of an upgrade from Citigroup, which has moved from neutral to buy with a target price lifted from 470p to 535p. Citi said:

The combination of recent, material upgrades to UK economic growth forecasts, and M&S management initiatives have markedly improved the credibility of double-digit 2015 and 2016 M&S earnings per share growth forecasts. We argue that this should underpin the group's current undemanding valuation metrics.
Primarily as a consequence of significant IT, logistics and supply chain investment programmes over the last 3-4 years, M&S General Merchandise should begin to see both revenue and gross margin improvements from 2014.
